B44: The Sicilian Defence is a chess opening that begins with the following moves:1.e4 c5ECOB20–B99OriginGiulio Cesare Polerio, 1594Named afterSicilyParentKing's Pawn Game. Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov are two of the most famous players to have played it.
D12: The Slav Defense is one of the primary defenses to the Queen's Gambit. It was analyzed as early as 1590, but not explored extensively until the 1920s. After 3...Nf6, the main line is 4.Nc3. Black can try the Winawer Countergambit, 3...e5.

D23: The Queen's Gambit Accepted is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 d52. c4 dxc4. 3.e4 is an old move that became popular again in the 1990s. The Alekhine Variation focuses on rapid development of pieces along with domination of the centre.
D24: The Queen's Gambit Accepted is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 d52. c4 dxc4. It is the third most popular option on Black's second move, after 2...e6 and 2...c6 (the Slav Defense)
B72: The Sicilian Defence is a chess opening that begins with the following moves:1.e4 c5ECOB20–B99OriginGiulio Cesare Polerio, 1594Named afterSicilyParentKing's Pawn Game. The Sicilian is the most played and most analysed opening at both the club and master levels.
B86: The Sicilian Defence is a chess opening that begins with the following moves:1.e4 c5ECOB20–B99OriginGiulio Cesare Polerio, 1594Named afterSicilyParentKing's Pawn Game. Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov are two of the most famous players to have played the Sicilian.
D70: The Grünfeld Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g63. Nc3 d5. Black offers White the possibility of 4.cxd5, which may be followed by 4...Nxd5 and 5.e4.
